title: China Economic Growth Slows Even More in Third Quarter
summary: It was the slowest growth since the first quarter of 1992 when China began publishing quarterly growth data. SHANGHAI-China's economy grew 6% in the third quarter, landing right on the central government's full-year baseline target for gross domestic product, as business activity continues to deteriorate in the world's No. 2 economy.

title: Hasenstab Built a Bond Franchise on Risky Bets. Now, He's Piling Up Cash.
summary: After losses, including in Argentina, star Franklin manager pulls out of most emerging markets. One of Wall Street's most intrepid bond investors has turned defensive.

title: Mulvaney Says Ukraine Aid Was Tied to Demand for DNC Server
summary: White House official later revises comments, says there was no link between aid and investigations. WASHINGTON-A top White House official for the first time linked President Trump's decision to hold up aid to Ukraine to his desire for Kyiv to probe a Democratic National Committee server related to the 2016 election, then hours later issued a statement contradicting his own remarks.

title: Rick Perry to Step Down as Energy Secretary
summary: Move comes after Perry said he called Giuliani at Trump's direction on Ukraine concerns. Energy Secretary Rick Perry announced his resignation Thursday amid growing scrutiny of his role in the president's interactions with Ukraine, including a subpoena from the House impeachment inquiry.

title: Businessmen Accused of Conspiring With Giuliani Associates Plead Not Guilty
summary: David Correia and Andrey Kukushkin charged with one count each in federal campaign-finance case. The Manhattan U.S. Attorney's office plans to produce "fairly voluminous" discovery in a campaign-finance case involving associates of Rudy Giuliani, a federal prosecutor said in court Thursday, including materials drawn from 10 search-warrant applications, email and electronic records for more than 10 accounts, and financial records from more than 50 bank accounts.

title: Vaping-Related Injury Cases Near 1,500, With 33 Deaths
summary: Public-health officials still don't know what specifically is causing mysterious illnesses. The number of lung injuries linked to vaping grew to 1,479 this week, with 33 deaths, federal health authorities said Thursday, as they ramp up laboratory testing to gain more insights into the still-mysterious illnesses.

title: GOP Senators Widen Divide With Trump on Syria
summary: Republicans join Democrats to introduce bill condemning troop pullback, a day after White House meeting with congressional leaders erupted. Republican lawmakers responded to President Trump's decision to pull U.S. troops out of Syria with phone calls to the White House, fiery floor speeches and legislation-crafted with Democrats-instructing Mr. Trump to explain his plan for Syria to Congress.

title: Seward's Folly: New York City Finally Is Filling a 1936 Work Order
summary: A 1936 request to replace the base of a statue of William H. Seward-a former 19th-century governor, senator and U.S. Secretary of State-is being executed. In 1936, Karl H. title: Turkey Agrees to Pause Military Operations in Northern Syria
summary: Five-day suspension comes with a U.S. pledge to facilitate a pullout by Syrian Kurdish fighters; Trump hails deal, but critics say it mainly fulfills Ankara's goals. Turkey agreed to suspend military operations in northern Syria for five days in return for a U.S. pledge to facilitate a pullout by Syrian Kurdish fighters, a deal President Trump hailed as "an amazing outcome," but that some critics said mainly fulfilled Turkish goals.

title: Congress to the Kurdish Rescue
summary: A Senate sanctions bill has Erdogan's attention-and Trump's.. President Trump hailed a "cease-fire" agreement with Turkey regarding Syria's Kurds on Thursday as a win for the diplomatic ages, thanking Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan with his usual restraint as "a hell of a leader. And he's a tough man. He's a strong man. And he did the right thing." It's more accurate to say Mr. Erdogan is looking down the barrel of serious bipartisan economic sanctions from the U.S. Congress.

title: Chicago Teachers Strike Again
summary: The union dictates terms of surrender to new Mayor Lightfoot.. In a popular children's book "Click, Clack, Moo," the cows refuse to produce milk and persuade some hens to stop laying eggs until a farmer acquiesces to their demands. After he concedes, the ducks go on strike. Welcome to Chicago, where teachers and their labor allies went on strike Thursday.

title: Landmark Plan to Replace Rikers Island Jail Is Approved
summary: Vote by New York City Council clears the way to build more modern facilities in four boroughs. The New York City Council on Thursday voted to approve a sweeping plan to replace the Rikers Island jail complex with four smaller neighborhood jails by 2026 to accommodate the city's goal of shrinking its inmate population.

title: UAW Officials Vote to Extend Nationwide GM Strike
summary: Walkout will continue until UAW members approve new labor deal. The United Auto Workers will continue to picket General Motors Co. 's U.S. factories until workers have approved a new labor deal, prolonging a costly nationwide strike that is already the company's longest in decades.

title: The Impeachment Needle May Soon Move
summary: The mood has shifted against Trump, but the House has to show good faith and seriousness.. Things are more fluid than they seem. That's my impression of Washington right now. There's something quiet going on, a mood shift.

title: India Needs Harvard as Well as Hard Work
summary: The scapegoating of a Nobel Prize-winning native demonstrates the pitfalls of nationalism.. What message should New Delhi take from a person of Indian origin winning the Nobel Prize for economics? In a nation increasingly characterized by bristly nativism, the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party ought to embrace, rather than reject, India's intellectual diaspora.

title: Tax Myths of Warrenomics
summary: Her advisers make three huge errors in denying the rich pay the government more.. Economists Emmanuel Saez and Gabriel Zucman of the University of California, Berkeley are advising Elizabeth Warren's presidential campaign and drawing generous media attention for their assertion that the U.S. tax system is flat-that the middle class and poor pay as great a share of their income in taxes as the rich. They're wrong, and three huge mistakes underlie their analysis.

title: How San Francisco Is Killing Its Restaurants
summary: Labor costs and regulation are ruining a once-thriving industry. Congress should take it as a cautionary tale.. San Francisco was once known for trendy restaurants with lines out the door. Today, the city's restaurateurs are concerned with keeping their doors open at all. Restaurant closings outpace openings by 9%, according to Yelp data analyzed by the Golden Gate Restaurant Association. In a recent meeting with the Board of Supervisors, one industry veteran said: "We need to do something now, or we will be gone."

title: Trump's Syria Exit Puts Yazidis in Peril
summary: ISIS will re-emerge as soon as the pressure lets up.. I am a Yazidi who was born and raised in Iraq. I worked for seven years as an interpreter for the U.S. Army in Iraq before immigrating to the U.S. in 2012. In 2014 I co-founded Yazda, a U.S.-based nongovernmental organization, to support the Yazidi community after ISIS orchestrated a genocide against the Yazidi people.

title: AT&T in Talks to Resolve Elliott Management's Activist Campaign
summary: Agreement could include board changes, strategic review. AT&T Inc. is in talks with Elliott Management Corp. to resolve the activist investor's campaign for change at the phone and media giant, people familiar with the matter said.

title: How to Make Pelosi and Schumer Angry
summary: Another bizarre 24 hours in Washington.. At her Thursday morning press conference Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi alleged "cowardice" and "cruelty" on the part of President Donald Trump. She also fielded more questions about her decision to walk out of a Wednesday meeting with Mr. Trump. But the story still doesn't entirely make sense.

title: Capra Could Cast Jimmy Stewart as Trump
summary: Mr. Smith went to Washington 80 years ago and encountered familiar obstacles.. 'He reminds me of the guy in 'The Wizard of Oz,' " Sen. Kamala Harris said of President Trump in last month's debate. "When you pull back the curtain, it's a really small dude." Mr. Trump's recent tweet touting his "great and unmatched wisdom" likewise called to mind "Oz the Great and Powerful." Yet a better comparison might be drawn to the title character in another 1939 classic, Frank Capra's smart political satire "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington," which made its debut 80 years ago Oct. 19.

title: Saudi Aramco Delays Launch of World's Largest IPO
summary: Saudi state-oil giant postpones listing in order to 'fine tune' aspects of planned share sale. Saudi Aramco has postponed the launch of its hotly anticipated initial public offering, the latest setback for what would be the world's largest-ever stock market listing.

title: 'Dad's Maybe Book' Review: A Veteran of Life
summary: The author of "The Things They Carried" and other war stories serves up words of fatherly wisdom to his two young sons.. 'What sticks to memory, often, are those odd little fragments that have no beginning and no end," Tim O'Brien wrote in "The Things They Carried" (1990), his landmark collection of short stories about Vietnam. His latest book, and first in more than 15 years, is a collection of such fragments, in the form of letters addressed to his young sons, Timmy and Tad, as well as anecdotes about raising them. Mr. O'Brien is an older father; his sons were born when he was in his late 50s. The reality that he likely won't be there to shepherd his children into adulthood is the impetus of "Dad's Maybe Book." "Life is fragile," Mr. O'Brien writes in the opening. "Hearts go still. So now, just in case, I want to tell you about your father, the man I think I am . . . the Tim who himself was once a Timmy."

title: SEC Seeks Ideas For Improving Small-Stock Trading
summary: The agency's chairman, Jay Clayton, asks for input on how to address complaints from companies. Regulators are looking for ways to make the U.S. stock market a better place for trading shares in small- and medium-size companies.

summary: Goldman has closed the valuation gap with Morgan Stanley. If it dodges some big risks, it could pull ahead.. Wall Street's two biggest stand-alone investment banks are starting to look more and more alike. But under the surface they offer some fairly different risks and opportunities for investors.

title: Sondland Criticizes Trump Over Efforts to Pressure Ukraine

summary: Paint maker says higher prices help offset lower sales volume. PPG Industries Inc. said broad manufacturing weakness in recent months dented its sales of coatings used by factories and car makers.

summary: IASB chairman calls amortization 'ugly as sin,' but also a necessary expense. title: IBM's New Hat Doesn't Cover Old Problems
summary: Newly acquired software maker helps tech giant's latest results, but not by enough. If nothing else, the folks at Red Hat will probably never feel unloved by their new adoptive parent.

summary: Democrats commit to establishing similar tax rates and potency standards for cannabis. The governors of New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania met to discuss vaping and the legalization of recreational marijuana in hopes of reaching a consensus on regional standards.

title: Catalonia Leader Pushes on Vote for Independence

BARCELONA-Catalonia's secessionist leader Thursday pledged another referendum on independence from Spain, after days of clashes between police and protesters left hundreds of people injured.

title: CSX, Union Pacific Battle to Win Back Customers
summary: Despite lower prices and better service, the freight railroads struggle with competition from trucks. CSX Corp. and Union Pacific Corp. are running faster railroads with longer trains and operating more efficiently. They have a bigger challenge ahead in winning over more shippers that remain skeptical after years of subpar service.

title: Trading, Tax Benefit Lift Morgan Stanley Profit
summary: Third-quarter results beat analysts' expectations. Shares jump.. Morgan Stanley 's third-quarter profit rose 3% from a year ago, the last major U.S. bank to skate through a period of global tensions and shifting markets.

title: Exchange Rates Deal $22.56 Billion Blow to Companies' Earnings
summary: Honeywell, Johnson & Johnson and Philip Morris in recent days reported hits from currency fluctuations. Uncertainty around tariff tensions, Britain's exit from the European Union and the state of the global economy is expected to drive foreign currency-related losses at North American and European companies in the coming months, following a $22.56 billion blow to balance sheets in the second quarter, according to a company that tracks exchange-rate effects.

title: 'Jojo Rabbit': Friends, Imaginary and Hidden
summary: A Hitler Youth recruit faces tensions between his new role and a secreted visitor in Taika Waititi's absurdist comedy.. Before I fall into killjoy mode on the subject of "Jojo Rabbit," let me recall the pleasure I've taken in Taika Waititi's off-kilter humor. His "Hunt for the Wilderpeople," with its New Zealand-wide manhunt for a rebellious kid and his curmudgeonly foster father, was a genial pretext for an unexpectedly affecting tale. His vampire mockumentary "What We Do In the Shadows," a collaboration with Jemaine Clement, was a genre prodigy, tonally flawless and deadpan droll. His new feature, adapted from a serious novel by Christine Leunens, is an absurdist comedy about a 10-year-old boy growing up Nazi in wartime Germany. The film doesn't lack for audacity, or ultimate purpose-it's against hate and in favor of love. But the adaptation isn't funny enough to sustain the style, which owes an overt debt to Mel Brooks and amounts to Springtime for Hitler Youth.

title: 'Maleficent: Mistress of Evil': Snoozing Beauty
summary: Angelina Jolie returns as the evil witch in the over-violent, under-fun sequel.. Evil abounds in "Maleficent: Mistress of Evil." It begins with a script that banishes fun from a violent saga of war between two kingdoms, and takes up long-term residence in the royal personage of a queen, played by Michelle Pfeiffer, alongside whose malevolence poor Maleficent seems a good-hearted, bat-winged version of a helicopter godmother.

title: Trump, the Turks, Kurds and Foreign Policy
summary: The president sent in troops with the clearly defined and limited mission of destroying the ISIS caliphate. Period. This mission having been accomplished, it's time to come home. I write in defense of President Trump's decision to withdraw combat troops from Syria, a view which is in stark opposition to the Journal's editorial board ("Trump's Syria Mess," Oct. 15, "With Friends Like the U.S.," Oct. 8) and several readers' letters in response (Oct. 15). The president sent in troops with the clearly defined and limited mission of destroying the ISIS caliphate. Period. This mission having been accomplished, it's time to come home without further American casualties. Military intervention in the ancient hostilities between the Turks and Kurds, both of whom are American allies, is both foolish and unauthorized by any lawful mandate I'm aware of.

title: Literary Interpretation of Impeachment Mess
summary: Your editorial "The Whistleblower Executive" (Oct. 3) and Karl Rove's same day" op-ed "Hurry Up and Impeach" are really about Captains Ahab and Queeg.. Your editorial "The Whistleblower Executive" (Oct. 3) and Karl Rove's same-day op-ed "Hurry Up and Impeach" are really about Captains Ahab and Queeg. While the progressives believe the 2016 election was stolen, President Trump is consumed by his belief in a conspiracy to remove him. There doesn't appear to be much wiggle room in these positions. One despairs that the sole accomplishment of the progressives these four years may be the meaningless impeachment of the president. On the other hand, the president may end up governing with a bunker mentality. Both hurt the country.

title: Why Many Smart Women Support President Trump
summary: I, too, am a college-educated, suburban woman. I respect President Trump's achievements and it doesn't matter to me that he has been married three times.. Regarding the Oct. 8 letter from Rosemary McDonough: I, too, am a college-educated, suburban woman. I am retired, and during President Trump's term my retirement fund has increased. I live in a heavily populated border state and am happy to see he is addressing the overabundance of people living here illegally. He has reduced my taxes, reduced government regulations thereby improving the business environment and giving my children and grandchildren more access to better, high-paying jobs, and he is protecting my health plan from a government takeover.

title: In Waters vs. Dershowitz, Maxine Has the Better Impeachment Case
summary: Rep. Maxine Waters is correct when she says that an impeachable offense is "whatever Congress says it is-there is no law.". Prof. Alan Dershowitz's "Hamilton Wouldn't Impeach Trump" (op-ed, Oct. 10) demonstrates that, contrary to his own premise, Rep. Maxine Waters is correct when she says that an impeachable offense is "whatever Congress says it is-there is no law." He says that impeachment by the House is "a quasi-legal process rather than an exclusively political one." It is entirely unclear what "quasi-legal process" means in this context. What is perfectly clear, however, is that no court-including the U.S. Supreme Court-would ever render a purportedly binding decision as to whether or not articles of impeachment passed by the House (whether against President Trump or any other president) properly allege "high crimes and misdemeanors" within the meaning of Article II, Section 4 of the Constitution. Prof. Dershowitz never even suggests that such judicial review would be possible. The absence of any judicial review is what a reasonable person would understand "there is no law" to mean here. Prof. Dershowitz concedes that ultimately "it is left to Congress" to interpret the words "high crimes and misdemeanors"; that is exactly Rep. Waters's point.

title: Powerful Storm Hits Northeast; Half-Million Without Power in Region
summary: Nor'easter brings high winds, up to 4 inches of rain; Maine, Massachusetts hit particularly hard. Hundreds of thousands of people in the Northeast were without power Thursday after a powerful storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to the region overnight.

summary: Messaging for the idea is complicated by other health proposals aired by the Democratic primary field. Support for Medicare for All is showing signs of slipping as top-tier Democratic presidential candidates Sens. title: Barclays CTO Helps Spearhead Female-Entrepreneurs Program
summary: Goal is for participants to build businesses that will become vendors for the bank, says John Stecher. title: 'Living With Yourself' Review: Be the Better Man
summary: When a melancholy ad man discovers a much-improved clone of himself, he reconsiders his life in this complex Netflix comedy.. This saga of a man with two selves that comes blasting to life in "Living With Yourself" (Friday, Netflix) makes its aspirations clear from the outset. In this eight-part tale of Miles Elliott (a heroic performance by Paul Rudd), mysteriously destined to be followed around by his clone, there's an unmistakable sense that all this dark fun has to do with serious matters. Life, for instance, and character and lessons to be learned. There's no missing the messaging that informs every eruption of terror, every plot turn-that wisdom is being dispensed here, insight on human predilections. A heavy burden for comedy.

title: Pentagon Awards Patriot Radar Deal to Raytheon
summary: Incumbent provider of missile-defense system wins three-way contest for contract valued at up to $5 billion. title: A Gleefully Gluttonous Long Weekend in New Orleans
summary: Resume Subscription. IF YOU HAVE FRIENDS in New Orleans you haven't heard from in a while, it's probably because they haven't had the energy to pick up the phone. But the intense heat of the last few months is finally starting to peel away, and the animated funkiness of the city is back on full display. The music, the food, the freedom to take adult beverages outside in go-cups-this 300-year-old port town thoroughly lives up to its hype during the autumn months but lacks the marauding tourist mobs you encounter during winter's Mardi Gras and spring's Jazz Fest. Not that this time of year wants for appetizing events: Crescent City Blues and BBQ Festival kicks off this Friday (Oct. 18-20) and, equally perilous to waistlines, the Po-Boy Festival, serving more than 60 versions of the locally revered sandwiches, falls on Nov. 3. If you're in town on a Sunday, expect to find locals cheering (and, often, praying) for the fate of the New Orleans Saints at nearly every bar

title: Manufacturing Sputters as Broader U.S. Economy Slows
summary: A loss of momentum in U.S. manufacturing aligns with weakening factory output overseas. WASHINGTON-U.S. manufacturing production fell in September, adding to evidence that slowing global growth and trade frictions are weighing on the economy.

title: Facebook Stands for Free Expression
summary: In a democracy, a private company shouldn't have the power to censor politicians or the news.. Since starting Facebook in 2004, I've focused on building services that give people voice and bring them together. Throughout history, these objectives have gone hand in hand-even if it doesn't feel that way today. Frederick Douglass once called free expression "the great moral renovator of society." Movements like #BlackLivesMatter and #MeToo depend on people openly sharing their experiences. And the ability to speak freely has been central in the global fight for democracy. Allowing greater numbers of people to share their perspectives is how society becomes more inclusive.

title: Juul Halts Online Sales of Some Flavored E-Cigarettes
summary: Move follows similar discontinuation in retail stores last year; online sales account for less than 10% of company's sales. summary: The agency plans for a walk from the International Space Station, months after canceling it because it didn't have the right spacesuit. title: Why It's Worth Knowing Who Imported Your Wine
summary: Looking to try an unfamiliar wine-with the reassurance that you're getting a quality bottle? Check the back label for the name of the importer. Here are a few you can trust to offer wines of character. IF I'M BROWSING for wine in a retail shop and chance upon an unfamiliar one, I'll turn the bottle around and check the back label for the name of the importer. That name may be writ small or large, depending on the importer's ego and/or typeface selection. Either way, it can be a useful indicator of the character, quality and even style of the wine.

summary: Markets have plenty of reasons to be cautious following Boris Johnson's deal to take the U.K. out of the European Union. title: How Technology Will Revolutionize Public Trust
summary: Though Americans increasingly distrust their institutions, digital platforms are spurring them to rely on one another like never before. Trust in major institutions seems to be collapsing in America in the era of "fake news," Russian bots on Facebook and tribal politics. A recent Pew Research Center poll found that about seven in 10 Americans say that trust in society-in government, in each other-is declining. And more than four in 10 Americans think that declining trust is "a very big problem."

title: At Home With the Tastemakers
summary: These food and beverage entrepreneurs are behind culinary brands both iconic and emerging. Home means something very different to each of them. title: Saudi Exchange Readies Aramco IPO. Investors Raise Concerns.
summary: Five years ago, the Tadawul market didn't allow foreigners to invest. Now it's readying to host one of the world's most anticipated listings.. Saudi Arabia's stock market has-in little less than half a decade-transformed itself by opening to international investors and instituting investor friendly reforms. But as it prepares to host the world's biggest initial public offering, of Aramco, some foreign investors remain concerned about market transparency and how heavily the government intervenes in Saudi shares.

title: Big Wine Estates in Small Town Napa Valley
summary: California's St. Helena is a charming community with luxe residential properties, vineyard views included. Sixty-five miles north of San Francisco and nestled between the Mayacamas and Vaca Mountain ranges, St. Helena is a scenic, 4-square-mile city centrally located in the heart of Napa Valley wine country. A significant portion of the town's roughly 6,000 people reside in the area year-round, from farmworkers to families with children. Silicon Valley executives have second homes here, and out-of-towners have vacation properties. Main Street, which has historic buildings dating back to the late 1800s and early 1900s, is lined with coffee shops, bakeries and restaurants, as well as clothing, jewelry and home boutiques. And then there is the wine scene: St. Helena is known for its vineyards that grow high-quality, premium grapes and wineries that produce some of the best vintages in the world.

title: The Making of Thomas Edison's Miraculous Machine
summary: In 1877, all of the inventor's past work on the sending and reception of sound coalesced into his greatest invention, the phonograph. Thomas Alva Edison's self-proclaimed greatest invention, the phonograph, won him overnight fame. Journalists would marvel that such an acoustic revolution, adding a whole new dimension to human memory, could have been accomplished by a man half deaf in one ear and wholly deaf in the other.

title: This Japanese Hotel is a Glorious Relic From a Lost World
summary: In an enchanting mountain town 90 minutes from Tokyo, the Nikko Kanaya Hotel still eerily evokes the early days of tourism in Japan. Plus: Japan's rapidly rising visitor numbers. THE 19TH-CENTURY FOREIGNERS who first ventured to the Japanese mountain town of Nikko came away enchanted by the scenery: ornate Shinto shrines set among rivers, forests and waterfalls. But those same visitors were less impressed with the lodging options. Many griped about the local inns, furnished with futon-beds set on the floor and paper walls that offered no privacy. And the food? Overly exotic at best. British traveler Isabella Bird offered a typical review: "The fishy and vegetable abominations known as 'Japanese food' can only be swallowed and digested by a few, and that after long practice." In 1873, in an attempt to cater to Western sensibilities, Zenichiro Kanaya, a 21-year-old temple musician, opened rooms in his family house, serving guests simply-prepared poultry, rainbow trout and eggs. Two decades later, Mr. Kanaya established the first European-style resort hotel nearby, with two stories, mattress beds and such Western staples as bread, which guests had taught his chefs to bake. By 1896, the Kanaya Hotel was turning out 14-course French menus with beef in Périgueux sauce and champignons au jus-not a piece of sushi or grain of rice in sight. Throughout the early 20th century, the hotel drew a parade of celebrity travelers, including the Japanophile Frank Lloyd Wright and, later, Albert Einstein and his wife, Elsa. The hotel gardens, sculpted by temple workers, fit in with the local aesthetic, while the kitchen continued to appease American and European palates, with bacon and eggs for breakfast and mille-feuille after dinner.

title: 'The Lighthouse': A Beacon of Hope in Cinematic Darkness
summary: Robert Eggers's horror-fantasy about a pair of men tending a lighthouse at the end of the 19th century is one of the most original films of the year.. Every now and then a movie beguiles your mind's eye. Watching it, you know you'll keep calling up images from it, along with feelings the images convey. "The Lighthouse" is a prime example. It's a horror fantasy by Robert Eggers, the visionary filmmaker who made his dark mark with "The Witch," his 2015 debut feature. That film was set in colonial New England in 1630, more than six decades before the first Salem witch trials. This one, which he wrote with his brother, Max Eggers, takes place more than two centuries later, in the late 1890s. The setting is a desolate island off the coast of Maine where two so-called wickies, a veteran lighthouse keeper and his younger assistant, tend a U.S. government lighthouse.

title: This Jamaican-Style Salmon Recipe Delivers the Sunshine You Crave
summary: Bright with ginger, chiles and vinegar, this salmon is a fresh take on classic Caribbean escovitch. GROWING UP in the Bronx, chef Kwame Onwuachi had ample opportunity to explore the Jamaican side of his heritage through food. "There was a place up on 233rd Street that made a really good escovitch," he recalled. Now he offers that Caribbean classic of fish doused in pickled vegetables at his restaurant Kith/Kin in Washington, D.C. But he does it his way: lighter, fresher.
